title: 114_s731
content: The Social Security Expansion Act includes provisions for across-the-board benefit increases, computation of cost-of-living adjustments, an increase in minimum benefits for low earners, and taxes on payroll, self-employment earnings, and investment gains. Section 215(a)(1)(B) of the Social Security Act is amended to increase benefits for individuals eligible for old-age or disability insurance after 2020. The increase varies from 1 percent in 2021 to a gradual increase by 1 percentage point annually from 2022 to 2034, and a fixed increase from 2035 onwards. The Social Security Act is amended to increase benefits gradually from 2021 to 2034, with a fixed increase of 15 percent starting in 2035. SEC. 3. COMPUTATION OF COST-OF-LIVING INCREASES. The text discusses amending the Social Security Act to define the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers (CPI-E) and its application to pre-1979 law. The Social Security Act is amended to include the Social Security Expansion Act and ensure adjustments under other laws are unaffected. The Bureau of Labor Statistics will publish the index for Elderly Consumers. The Social Security Act is amended to include the Social Security Expansion Act and ensure adjustments under other laws are unaffected. The Bureau of Labor Statistics will publish the "Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers" for cost-of-living computations. The amendments will apply to determinations made after September 30 of the second calendar year following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Increase in minimum benefit for lifetime low earners based on years in the workforce. Increase in minimum benefit for lifetime low earners based on years in the workforce, effective after 2015, ensures that no primary insurance amount computed under certain conditions can be less than a specified minimum monthly amount. The clause specifies the applicable percentage of the annual dollar amount determined for the year. The applicable percentage is based on the number of years of work as specified in a table. The applicable percentage is determined based on the number of years of work according to a specified table. The applicable percentage for determining annual dollar amounts is based on the number of years of work according to a specified table, with increments ranging from 68.75 percent for 21 years to 125.00 percent for 30 or more years. The annual dollar amount for a calendar year after 2016 is determined by multiplying the 2016 amount by the ratio of the national average wage index for the second calendar year before the year in question to the index for 2014. The terms 'year of work' and 'poverty guideline for 2015' are defined within this context. The Department of Health and Human Services published amendments to the Social Security Act, requiring recomputation of insurance amounts prior to November 2014. A conforming amendment was made to section 209(k)(1) of the Act. SEC. 5. Payroll tax on remuneration up to contribution and benefit base and more than $250,000. Amends section 3121(a) of the Internal Revenue Code for calendar years when the contribution and benefit base is less than $250,000. Applies to remuneration paid after December 31, 2015. Tax on net earnings from self-employment up to contribution and benefit base and more than $250,000. The tax on net earnings from self-employment is calculated based on the excess of earnings over the contribution and benefit base, minus wages paid to the individual. The tax on net earnings from self-employment is calculated based on the excess of earnings over the contribution and benefit base, minus wages paid to the individual. Subsection (b) of section 1402 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to apply only to taxable years beginning in calendar. The tax on net earnings from self-employment is amended to apply to taxable years beginning in calendar years where the contribution and benefit base is less than $250,000. The amendments are effective for earnings derived after December 31, 2015. Tax on investment gain is addressed in Section 7. Section 7 addresses the tax on investment gains, amending the Internal Revenue Code to increase the rate from 3.8 percent to 10 percent. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code by adding "AND SOCIAL SECURITY" after "MEDICARE." Trust funds related to the Federal old-age and survivors insurance trust fund are also adjusted to allocate 62 percent of taxes imposed under section 1411 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments in this section increase the tax rate on investment gains from 3.8 percent to 10 percent and allocate 9 percent of taxes to the Federal disability insurance trust fund. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2015.
